topic: Indian States ‚Üí Capitals, Rivers, Festivals, Dances

sections.1_story_intuition: Indian states are diverse in culture, geography, and traditions. Each state has its own capital, major rivers, unique festivals, and traditional dances. These facts are frequently asked in competitive exams. Mastering this topic helps candidates answer static GK questions about Indian states quickly and accurately.
2_key_definitions: State: Administrative division of India with its own government.
Capital: City where the state government is based.
River: Large natural stream of water flowing through a state.
Festival: Cultural or religious celebration unique to a state.
Dance: Traditional form of artistic movement.
Union Territory: Region governed directly by the central government.
Official Language: Language recognized by the state government.
Harvest Festival: Festival celebrating the harvest season.
State Symbol: Official emblem, animal, or bird of a state.
3_key_facts_data_points: India has 28 states and 8 union territories.
Uttar Pradesh: Capital - Lucknow; River - Ganga; Festival - Diwali; Dance - Kathak.
Maharashtra: Capital - Mumbai; River - Godavari; Festival - Ganesh Chaturthi; Dance - Lavani.
West Bengal: Capital - Kolkata; River - Hooghly; Festival - Durga Puja; Dance - Chhau.
Tamil Nadu: Capital - Chennai; River - Kaveri; Festival - Pongal; Dance - Bharatanatyam.
Punjab: Capital - Chandigarh; River - Sutlej; Festival - Baisakhi; Dance - Bhangra.
Kerala: Capital - Thiruvananthapuram; River - Periyar; Festival - Onam; Dance - Kathakali.
Assam: Capital - Dispur; River - Brahmaputra; Festival - Bihu; Dance - Bihu.
Gujarat: Capital - Gandhinagar; River - Sabarmati; Festival - Navratri; Dance - Garba.
Odisha: Capital - Bhubaneswar; River - Mahanadi; Festival - Rath Yatra; Dance - Odissi.
Rajasthan: Capital - Jaipur; River - Chambal; Festival - Teej; Dance - Ghoomar.
Karnataka: Capital - Bengaluru; River - Krishna; Festival - Ugadi; Dance - Yakshagana.
Madhya Pradesh: Capital - Bhopal; River - Narmada; Festival - Lokrang; Dance - Rai.
Andhra Pradesh: Capital - Amaravati; River - Godavari; Festival - Ugadi; Dance - Kuchipudi.
Bihar: Capital - Patna; River - Ganga; Festival - Chhath Puja; Dance - Jat-Jatin.
Goa: Capital - Panaji; River - Mandovi; Festival - Carnival; Dance - Fugdi.
4_micro_notes: OD: Bhubaneswar, Mahanadi, Rath Yatra, Odissi.
5_exam_capsules: What is the capital of Uttar Pradesh? Lucknow.
Which river flows through Maharashtra? Godavari.
What is the main festival of West Bengal? Durga Puja.
Which dance is famous in Tamil Nadu? Bharatanatyam.
What is the capital of Punjab? Chandigarh.
Which river flows through Kerala? Periyar.
What is the main festival of Assam? Bihu.
Which dance is famous in Gujarat? Garba.
What is the capital of Odisha? Bhubaneswar.
Which river flows through Rajasthan? Chambal.
What is the main festival of Karnataka? Ugadi.
Which dance is famous in Andhra Pradesh? Kuchipudi.
What is the capital of Bihar? Patna.
Which river flows through Goa? Mandovi.
What is the main festival of Goa? Carnival.
7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up rivers of North and South India.
Assuming all states have the same festivals.
Mixing up capitals and largest cities.
Assuming all rivers flow through capitals.
Assuming all states have unique dances.
Confusing state symbols with national symbols.

8_case_study_context.title: Kerala: Onam and Kathakali
8_case_study_context.explanation: Kerala is known for the harvest festival Onam and the classical dance Kathakali. Onam celebrates the homecoming of King Mahabali and is marked by boat races, flower decorations, and feasts. Kathakali is a traditional dance-drama known for its elaborate costumes and makeup.
